body_html:
[…] that way the license will legally hold up. It's just a matter of mentioning the contributors in a GH issue and asking them to say they agree.

It would certainly be 'cleaner', aye. I'm just not very optimistic about people actually responding.

Personally I would argue AGPL is a more suitable license, given the type of project. I don't see why companies should be allowed to build a closed source commercial product out of this code base.

I don't really care about the license besides trying to avoid restrictive (read: copylefted) ones where I can. But that discussion can get esoteric soon so yeah, AGPL would work, too.
